Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanotyping Platform for Studies of Soft Biological Matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to UCLA to develop a high throughput Mechanotyping Platform (MTP). Mechanical properties of cells and nuclei are implicated in a wide range of biological contexts: they are central for determining how physical forces alter gene expression, and more broadly they can signal a transformation in a cell?s physiological state, such as in malignant transformation. However, to advance our fundamental understanding of the mechanisms underlying cell/nuclear mechanical properties requires probing the mechanical properties of cells and nuclei across genetic and physical phase space; this demands measurements of a large number of samples and single cells which cannot be achieved on a feasible timescale using existing methods. MTP offers dramatic improvements over current techniques in time, cost, and user-accessibility, and is comprised of two independent technologies: (1) High Throughput Mechanical Screening (HTMS) instrumentation simultaneously probes the deformability of hundreds of individual samples by subjecting them to external stresses, forcing them to deform through micron-scale pores, and determining the number of passaged cells; this provides a physiologically relevant assay to detect relative mechanical changes that have direct implications for the circulation and perfusion of cells through vasculature and tissues. (2) A Mechanical Probing System (MaPS) measures elastic moduli directly from single cells and nuclei at rates of 100 per second by flowing cells through a microfluidic channel, poking the cell with a force probe embedded in the channel, and determining the resultant deformation; this will enable reproducible measurements of the mechanical properties of single cells at unprecedented speeds. The proposed research will establish a framework for mechanotyping that will be accessible to biological researchers in fields ranging from stem cells to cancer biology. Probing the mechanical signatures of cells can also provide an alternative approach to classify and treat a wide range of diseases. In addition, this research will provide critical insight into the molecular origins of mechanical phenotype, heterogeneity within a population of single cells, and more broadly, will transform the search for crucial information in biological research by exploiting the inherent texture or mechanotype of individual cells.

The educational objective of this project is to engage undergraduate and high school students, as well as general audiences, in science using food and cooking as pedagogical tools. Communicating sophisticated scientific and technological concepts using food is a tactile, innovative, and tasty approach that is proving to be popular and effective in promoting the public understanding of science and technology. Curricula will be disseminated through online modules and interactive lectures to populations of high school students, especially groups underrepresented in science. Undergraduate students will be engaged in learning science in a classroom setting through inquiry-driven projects, such as engineering an apple pie. The public understanding of science will be promoted through interactive events, including a Scientific Bake-off. These education and outreach activities will pioneer methodologies in multisensory
science education using food and cooking. Promoting knowledge of science and food also addresses America's pressing need to improve eating and health issues for socio-economically-stratified communities. More information is available at www.scienceandfood.org.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: 4/1/2013 – 3/31/2018

CAREER: Mechanotyping Platform for Studies of Soft Biological Matter

The inherent stiffness or squishiness cells can have major implications for health and disease. Some types of cells need to deform as they circulate through our bodies, while other cells need to be stiffer to survive mechanical forces they may experience in tissues or organs. Understanding the intrinsic deformability of cells in disease states can provide a lens into how cellular functions may go awry. This NSF CAREER Award supported the development of a new technology platform that consists of three new methods that we invented to achieve improved measurements of cellular deformability:  1) more quickly—existing methods measure one sample at a time, but our ‘parallel microfiltration’ method enables us to measure ~100 samples at once (Fig 1); and 2) with improved accuracy—our ‘quantitative deformability cytometry’ method enables calibrated measurements of cell stiffness, which provides a way to compare measurements in different laboratories (Fig 2). Our platform is based on studying how quickly cells can flow through narrow gaps: ‘parallel microfiltration’ method relies on filtering cells in liquid through pores that are smaller than their own diameter (akin to boba tea) (Fig 1). In ‘quantitative deformability cytometry’ we flow cells through narrow channels and measure how they deform using a microscope and high speed camera (Fig 2). Using knowledge of physics enables us to interpret these data and extract measurements of cell deformability or stiffness. We also developed a novel force probe that is embedded in a flow channel; this enables us to poke cells many times per second and measure their deformability response to achieve even faster measurements of cell stiffness. These deformability measurement methods have diverse applications from white blood cells to cancer cells. For example, we have shown that cancer cells that do not respond to chemotherapy are more deformable than drug-sensitive cells. We also established that we can detect the effects of molecules that have anti-cancer effects and make cancer cells less invasive. Our findings establish how we can exploit the inherent texture or deformability of individual cells to search through large collections of molecules to find new drugs. These inventions also have translational potential; several companies are interested in partnership with us to pursue commercialization.

This Award also supported the development of new and engaging science curriculum for both undergraduate and high school students, as well as general audiences. We developed an undergraduate course on cell biophysics with a focus on mechanical aspects of biology; in this inquiry-driven course, students read and critique the scientific literature including seminal papers and recent studies in the field, including our recent cell deformability studies using the methods we invented. To communicate science to non-science students, the PI uses examples from food and cooking: the Science & Food undergraduate course has engaged hundreds of students at UCLA throughout the Award. These students have had the unique opportunity to learn how to be scientists through investigating scientific aspects of pie, conducting experiments, and presenting their results in the Annual Scientific Bake-Off. The Award also supported our study that discovered how integrating taste tests into the classroom can enhance how students learn science. To engage the broader community in science, a series of annual high profile public events attracted thousands of Los Angeles community members to learn about scientific aspects of food-related topics, from food waste to the role of science and technology in the future of food production. The PI also leads a Science & Food blog, which launches new content on a weekly basis and maintains an active following of thousands of readers in partnership with Discover Magazine. More information is available at www.scienceandfood.org.

A Supplement to this Award to Broaden Participation in Science supported the successful development of science curriculum that is based on food and gardening. The lesson plans that we have produced are aligned with Next Generation Science Standards and provide interactive activities that can be translated to high school science education. To develop this curriculum, we worked closely with a continuation high school to promote science among students who are underrepresented in science.
